summary.p: This manuscript was copied from a lithograph of the Amarakośaviveka of Maheśvara, also known as the Amaraviveka or Śiśubodhinī. Although the lithograph was printed in Devanāgarī script, this manuscript is written in Nandināgarī. Some of the marginalia, such as running margin titles, have been reproduced, but only on the first two folios. Notably, the table of contents after the first kāṇḍa has been copied from the lithograph.

This commentary on the Amarakośa was particularly popular in the late 19th and early 20th century, going through multiple editions as a lithograph as well as a printed book. As stated in the introductory stanzas, it was edited and expanded by Rāghunātha Talekar, under the supervision of Thomas Candy. The lithograph is particularly notable for its use of Western quotation marks, as explained in the introduction. The Nandināgarī scribe of this manuscript, however, did not seem to recognize them, and renders opening quotes as a two forward slashes and closing quotes as the number 11.
This manuscript contains the first kāṇḍa and part of the second kāṇḍa, along with 61 blank folios at the end.

collation.desc: Nandināgarī numerals, top-left, recto. 1-71 for the first kāṇḍa with table of contents. Foliation restarts at 1 for the second kāṇḍa, just as in the lithograph.

handNote.desc: Devanāgarī-style numerals occasionally used. Uninked, apart from the first and last folios.

additions.desc: A table of contents after the first kāṇḍa, corresponding to the lithograph. Titled || amarakośaprathamakāṇḍasya vargānukrameṇa ślokasaṃkhyā ||.
amara in the left margin, kośa in the right margin, 1v.
a· ko· ṭīḥ in the left margin, 2v.

origin.origDate: The introductory stanzas, copied from the lithograph, reads dvisaptasapteṃdumite śāke puṇyākhyapattane ||, indicating a śaka date of 1772, or 1850-51 CE. However, other editions of the lithograph contain two dates, one at the beginning and one at the end.
